title: How does something come from nothing and create everything when there isn't anything to begin with? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q: “How does everything come from nothing, without there being anything to begin with?” …Short answer: “It can’t!” Science is the most reliable tool we have for discovering the truth about all that we see and experience from a human perspective. Unfortunately, sometimes even science is at a loss on explaining certain events, happenings and conditions that we know take place within our universe. Science cannot explain gravity, the existence of the human consciousness, what’s happening inside black holes, self-awareness, the origins of life, love, perseverance or even where a single individual thought comes from. One of the greatest mysteries that has boggled history’s most renowned intellectuals and scientists is offering a definitive answer as to how our universe came to be. The two most intellectually-supported quantum theories regarding the origin of our universe are the Big Bang theory and the New Model Quantum Equation. The Big Bang theory proposes that our universe began at a point of singularity. All matter was tightly compressed into a single state of “somethingness” to which a series of expanding and contracting pressures produced a cosmic explosion of universal proportions. What happened before this point of singularity is a complete mystery. The New Model Quantum Equation takes the Big Bang theory one step further and proposes that the universe remains in a constant state of flux with the potential of re-occurring Big Bangs happening throughout infinity. This newer, updated quantum theory attempts to compensate for the Big Bang’s apparent breakdown of the laws of physics right at the point of singularity. Yes, you read that correctly. Science has two diametrically-opposed explanations for the origin of our universe.  Although both of these popular quantum theories offer explanations for how our universe came to be, neither offers an explanation as to where everything came from to start with in order for our universe to ultimately “be.” So how does science explain something coming from nothing? …You might be surprised at the answer: Science becomes a politician! Science likes to deal with logic and reason. Logic and reason are safe, reliable and repeatable methods for processing data. Anything that does not directly follow logic, the laws of physics and various other governing rules of the universe is considered “supernatural.” Science hates anything that appears to be supernatural and seeks to logically explain its true nature. However, since science cannot explain how one single photon, quark, particle or molecule exists in our universe, it resorts to what politicians do when they are faced with a question they cannot answer… They marginalize the question! Rather than accept the fact that science is totally baffled on how something can come from nothing, it attempts to re-define what “nothingness” actually is. What science has oddly chosen to do is to sacrifice its cornerstone of logic and reason in behalf of celestial conjecture and semantic sorcery. Science now attempts to convince us that “nothing” isn’t really what we think it is.  “Empty space is a bubbling brew of virtual particles that are popping in and out of existence at a timescale so short you can’t see them.” - Lawrence Krauss So there you have it! Apparently, “nothing” can have a certain amount of weight, volume, exhibit fluctuations of energy and have exciting little things simultaneously happening within it. ………..Who knew? Whereas at one time, “Nothing” was clearly, accurately and logically defined as, “a condition or state which is void of all things” has now been re-defined as an apparent “something” that has a measurable weight, volume and a litany of “virtual somethings” that spontaneously appear and disappear within it.  Since science cannot explain how something comes from nothing, it forwards a curious new definition of what certain “somethings” are and summarily declares them as being a byproduct of “nothing.” However, for the rest of us non-quantum-theory-savvy people, “nothing” is still defined as being empty, void of anything and everything that exists. Nothing cannot be something and something cannot be nothing. They are mutually-exclusive. Where one is found, the other cannot be! You cannot take “nothingness” and have something magically appear within it and then claim that it came form nothing because this “nothingness” was actually made up of these “something(s)” all along. …A Creationists might humorously regard this type of thinking as the, “Science of the Gaps.”

The unstable nothing fel apart into two directions, with the same amount of matter and anti-matter, keeping everything perfectly balanced. Since the real endpoint of this mirror universe is our beginning (i.e. the Big Bang) and vice versa, which may sound like an oxymoron, technically both universes retroactively created each other, forming an infinite closed loop, also holding each others future, present and past, with a certain degree of uncertainty.  With the interaction between them (or seen as one universe pulsing in real and imaginary time) behaving like for example D-Branes, like in String Theory (or M-theory or K-theory), causing the weird quantum behavior, vacuum polarizations, etc., but possibly phenomena like dark matter and dark energy as well..

What exactly is “existence”? What do you mean when you say something exists? Do you mean something exists because you are are able to touch and feel it? The only way you can feel something is if electrical signals are transmitted from that thing, via the neural network, into the brain, where it is translated so that you can understand what that thing is - what we call feelings. Apart from the fact that feelings are merely electrical signals translated by the brain, the thing you call “touch” has multiple layers of illusions: First, you are not actually fully grasping or touching anything. For there exists between your hand and the object you are touching, a force field caused by the repulsive forces between electrons on both surfaces of the bodies involved in the “touching”. There is tension acting in a scalar manner… Second, both your hand and the object you are supposedly touching, are illusions of a highly complex degree. For they only appear to be solid to the naked eye, while in reality, they are merely illusions of motion. Your hand, and so is the rest of your body, are made up of light particles under violent motion and in a state of high compression. Think of a bicycle wheel spinning with its metallic spokes when visualizing the illusions of your body…. you will find that the bicycle wheel appears to form a solid circle from far and will in fact act like a solid object if you try to bounce a rock off of it…but it is just motion!! So what then is existence? What is real? Is the motion of a thing the same as the thing? Is the motion of the bicycle wheel the same as the bicycle wheel? If our bodies and all of matter is made up of only motion, and motion is not real, then what is real? Who then are we? At the end of the day, it only makes sense if we think of ourselves as only idea, represented by form in a universe full of illusion. Idea is the only thing in the universe that does not end once created. It goes on forever morphing into many forms…the idea of the car, the idea of the Apple, the idea of man are all forms of realities represented by form/matter/spinning particles. Form follows idea, and not the other way around. Even your brain knows this, for it will create an instant image of the the idea you think about. Think about a goat, and the form of the goat appears…think of a cat, and it is there! Form follows idea. Mind is the idea. Energy is mind's tool, and form is the mind's canvas. Since energy can never be created, nor can it be destroyed, and we know that the Mind(idea) uses it as a tool, why then do we think the mind had a beginning? The Mind has no beginning, nor will it have an end. So to answer your question, I would say that there is no time, for ideas have never stopped and the mind has never been created. Everything exists in the NOW! TIME is an ILLUSION of MOTION!

Question: How does something come from nothing and create everything when there isn't anything to begin with?Answer: Thanks for the A2A.  I am not sure if this is an honest question or an attempt to say "gotcha", but I will answer as if the question is an honest one. There are "thought errors" in your question. 1) How does something come from nothing- we do not know that there was nothing.  We think that there was a singularity that was preceded by a  period of great density and high temperature.  What preceded this is unknown.  Is it possible that there was another Universe that had reached its death and that in its final expansion of heat and energy actually created the new universe?  Is it possible that this is actually how each universe gets created, by the death of the previous one?  Of course this is possible, we do not have the answer yet.  Is it possible that a god created our universe? Again yes this is possible.  Does it require a god?  Current evidence suggests that No god is required but again we have not reached a solid conclusion. The answer we have achieved in the last 50 years of our existence on this planet are themselves amazing.  The next 50 years will bring even more amazing answers, some of which may actual contradict the current answers.  That is what is great about science, it does not say "this is the answer so stop looking" it says " this is what we think based on the current evidence but keep looking and you might find a better answer". 2) Create everything: the term create carries an implied creator.  Evolution began immediately after the singularity, if the evidence is correct.  The Universe: Big Bang to Now in 10 Easy Steps 3) When there wasn't anything to begin with: assumption of the worse kind as we do not know that there was "nothing to begin with".  We do not currently have the technology to answer all these questions but that is okay.  I DON'T KNOW is a valid answer and much better then "GOD DID IT". The difference between the Theists stance and the Atheist stance is the Theists allow their Truth to become their Perception.  They operate by Faith not by Evidence so their Truth is inflexible.  Atheists allow their Perception to become their Truth and we not only allow our Perceptions to be altered by evidence but we expect it to be.  Our Truths therefore are flexible.  We could accept the evidence that a GOD or GODS exists if the evidence was credible, verifiable, independently obtainable or observable and repeatable.  Theist cannot accept the evidence, no matter how credible, to refute their Faith. Again, thanks for the A2A. I assume that you knew I was an Atheist when you asked this me to answer so you already had some clue as to how I would answer this question.

Presently I’m working on a revision of what I call my “Causal Argument in Abbreviated Form”; that addresses the question. But more than that, it actually tosses out a rationally grounded solution to Kant’s critical challenge, which addresses your question. The question belongs to the branch of philosophy called metaphysics. For myself I limit metaphysics to the Kantian definition … this means, as a science. What’s a science of metaphysics for Kant? A science for Kant would consist of a priori judgments or principles. But the caveat is that these principles would have to help us make sense of the world of our practical experience. How can metaphysics do that? It’s not all that easy to answer this question but then again, neither is it impossible. The first thing we have to do is shed ourselves of our practical common-sensed notions about reality. When dealing with cosmological questions such as yours common sense can only take us so far, that’s why Immanuel Kant (in his “Critique of Pure Reason” and follow up work “Prolegomena to Any Future Metaphysic That Might be Brought Forth as a Science”, states there can be no appeal to what he calls “the magic wand of so-called common sense.” I don’t dispense with this magic wand altogether however. There’s a proper balance that can be achieved between our common sense and our critical reasoning. For starters, think about the concept of nothing, as a state wherein all complexity has been washed away. What do we have? We have not just our common sensed practical dictionary definition of nothing, for there’s nothing in existence to frame our use of this practical definition. If all complexity is washed away then there is simply a Void. So again, what do we have? We have not nothing, but we have an Absolute state. What’s the grounds for postulating this when all we have is a Void? It’s absolute for such an empty concept, emptied of all complexity, resists our imposing on it any arbitrary limitation, and it’s as simple as that. We are finite beings and as such we are not capable of grasping by our mere thinking alone, the totality of that which reaches out to infinity. We can only possess an abstract concept of such a state, and so the concept of this Void presents to us an absolute concept. This is a critical insight that Kant failed to notice, but I have to be careful here for Kant also gave out a clue that maybe he did notice this, only he didn’t come right out and say it clearly. And for an answer to the apparent dilemma of how something followed from this state, the only instrument that we have to guide us on our path toward answers is pure speculative reason. It’s a question that lies outside the scope of our sciences, even though science may point in the right direction for our reason to follow in its quest for a solution. My response to Kant is at causalargument.com, if you care to peruse it, or just glimpse at it … and if you do, you’ll find I’ve given the subject some serious thought. The revised Abbreviated Version should be uploaded within a week or so, baring any unforeseen delays.

Nothing, in the philosophical sense of absolute nothingness, is not a valid physical concept. Absolute nothingness is what is not possible. It could never have been. It is however quite plausible that time, space, and the quantum fields have never not existed (the double negative makes sense here), which doesn’t mean that time has an infinite past, only that without time existence has no meaning. The quantum fields fluctuate continuously and a large enough fluctuation would be enough to produce our universe. It didn’t take as much as you might think. Alan Guth has recently said that inflation could have been triggered by as little as one gram of matter in a space one billionth the size of a proton. This is within the realm of possible, albeit rare, quantum fluctuations. It was inflation that stabilized matter, while amplifying that gram into all of the matter/energy into our entire universe (about 1000 times the size of the currently observable universe), set entropy on its way toward infinity, gave time its arrow and space its dimensions, and linked them all together. Our universe was not impossible, it was inevitable, and so would be universes before and after ours.

It’d seem that neither “everything”, “nothing” or even “something” is a stable condition. The one stable condition would seem to be: changeOr as it is said so well in French: Plus ça change, plus c'est la même chose. Etymology An epigram by Jean-Baptiste Alphonse Karr in the January 1849 issue of his journal Les Guêpes (“The Wasps”). Literally “The more it changes, the more it’s the same thing.” . . . Proverb plus ça change, plus c'est la même chose the more things change, the more they stay the same The underlying logic Seriously, conceptually or logically it seems change being more basic than both everything and nothing would seem to be enough. That would imply that verbs are more interesting to us than nouns, which is to say that perhaps we should view particles and waves and all that more as events than “stuff”. [1] When we are speaking of processes, we are not surprised when we notice that Event B follows from Event A, and that Event C follows after Event B. Process implies change. So perhaps we should speak not of no thing and some thing or every thing but rather something like this: Formula: no event → some event or every event Yet that violates a basic rule, the one which says that nothing comes from nothing (ex nihilo).  Ex nihilo But perhaps nothing is not the nothing we thought we knew. Perhaps nothing isn’t empty (or how to put it). Perhaps empty is more like open than void. If so, the everything once upon a time seeming to come into existence ex nihilo could be about something coming from “the openness” rather than “the emptiness”. If nothing can be something while being nothing, for being open is being something, even if empty, then nature may be obeying also another old rule, practically the same one in different clothing, which says that nature does not make jumps (natura non facit saltus).  A pause And, here’s the catch (or one possible catch), “No event” is what you have in a pause. When you have something building up to critical mass, you have “no” event, here meaning no discernible event. Yet, when critical mass is reached, suddenly something happens. Why should we not be able to have that pause first? That is, nature doesn’t necessarily make jumps big enough for us to notice. Formula: no event → some invisibly small event → some other invisibly small event → another other invisibly small event → yet another invisibly small event → some indiscernible event → one more → some event no one notices yet again → some such event one more time → third’s a charm but no one there to see the tree falling-event → some other completely unknown event → infinitely many more of these → oops critical mass!!!! → all events start happening (Big Bang) The Big Bang as the limit after an infinitely long no-time of openness. Waves/potentialities coalescing into actuality, into point particles, time and space. Critical mass is practically the same term as quantum. Things may have been going on for ages and ages (timelessly, somehow) before the Big Bang, just not discernible, just not enough to reach critical mass and set the whole process off. So, that’s my suggestion: everything and nothing are better rephrased into categories that are process-based rather than “stuff”-based, in which case the question doesn’t seem that puzzling anymore. …………………………….. We seem to get variations on this question daily, and they are all posed in a way that make you think the person has been listening to too many creationist-types. No one posits that the universe came from “nothing”. That is not what the Standard Model Of Physics says. Rather, the Standard Model maintains that at the beginning of the universe, the “singularity” was a point of almost-infinitely-hot and almost-infinitely-compressed energy. There is no limit to temperature or density for energy. The energy represented by the singularity became the observable universe. What we do NOT know is why this situation obtained in the first place, or why the singularity expanded (“inflated”) and began to cool, causing the precipitation of the basic building blocks of matter… the subatomic particles. There are a number of hypotheses, but they are pretty “heady” stuff. Any good contemporary book on cosmology or astrophysics should provide some insight.
